#Text=2 .
#Text=Safety Analysis Framework for Complex Electromechanical
#Text=Equipment System
#Text=Based on STAMP
#Text=STAMP treats safety as a control problem , and the focus of system safety is changed from preventing failures in implementing safety constraints .
#Text=It still contains component failures , but it extends the concept of accidental causes to include component interactions .
#Text=It contains three main concepts : safety constraints , hierarchical control structures , and process models .
#Text=The most basic concept in STAMP is not an event but a constraint .

#Text=The main causes of safety issues in the new theory are component failures , system external disturbances , interactions between components , and component behaviors that lead to dangerous system states .
#Text=2.1 .
#Text=Principles of STAMP
#Text=The safety of a complex system is more than component failure or reliability decline .
#Text=In STAMP , safety is an emergent or system property , rather than a component property .
#Text=In system theory , complex systems are viewed as a hierarchy of organizational levels .
#Text=A hierarchical multilevel model of stakeholders is posited in STAMP , like the model of Rasmussen , but more expanded .
#Text=Another basic concept in STAMP is safety constraints .
#Text=In system theory , safety can be regarded as an emergent which is originated from interactions between components .
#Text=The method of controlling the emergent is to impose constraints on the behavior of the components and the interactions between the components .

#Text=Meanwhile , due to the constraint property of hierarchical structure , the accidents will happen if the higher layers cannot provide enough constraints or the lower layers violate the safety constraints when the high-level constraints control the behavior of the lower layers .

#Text=With the development of the equipment toward automation and intelligent , the system becomes more and more complex , and the difficulty in identifying and executing safety constraints in design and operation has been increased .
#Text=Figure 3
#Text=shows a general socio-technical system control structure from STAMP , which does not represent any particular system .
#Text=Each node in the graph is a human or machine component in a socio-technical system .
#Text=Connecting lines show control actions used to enforce safety constraints on the system and feedback that provides information to the controlling entity .
#Text=Besides constraints and hierarchical models , a third basic concept in STAMP is that of process models .
#Text=The process model is an important part of the control theory .
#Text=A typical process model consists of the controller that issued the command and the controlled object that provided the feedback ( controlled process ) , which is shown in
#Text=Figure 4
#Text=.
#Text=Usually , the controller contains process model and control algorithm .

#Text=When the controller sends a command to controlled process , the corresponding feedback which is generated by controlled process will be sent to controller to form a complete controlled process .
#Text=Component interaction accidents can often be interpreted as process model errors .
#Text=When the controller ’s process model does not match the controlled system or the controller issues an unsafe command , an accident will also happen .
#Text=Based on three basic concepts of STAMP , the basic casual factors of a standard control loop under the STAMP framework was concluded in
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=.
#Text=2.2 .
#Text=Comparison between FTA , FMECA , HAZOP , and STAMP
#Text=Traditional risk analysis theory considers hazards as the result of the action of a series of events .

#Text=The considered events usually involve several types of component failures or human errors , mainly adopting the forward sequence method ( such as failure mode and impact analysis ) or the backward sequence method ( Such as the fault tree directly describes the linear relationship between the failure and the influencing factors and is suitable for analyzing the hazard caused by the failure of a physical component or a simple system . )

#Text=Three hazard analysis techniques are suggested in the functional safety standard ( ISO26262 ) : fault tree analysis ( FTA ) , failure modes and effects analysis ( FMEA ) , and hazard and operability ( HAZOP ) analysis .
#Text=Table 2 summaries and compares three general hazard analysis techniques with STAMP .
#Text=FTA , FMECA , and HAZOP are proposed before the 1980s in which industrial automation and intelligence are still not highly dependent .
#Text=Only giant companies and some research institutes like the nuclear industry , aerospace , and universities have enough human and material resources to carry out relevant technology research .
#Text=Although some detail can be found by these three methods , the limitation of methods shown in Table 2 is clear .
#Text=These traditional safety analysis methods based on the event chain model are unable to do as much as they can when dealing with computer-oriented automated control system .

#Text=However , due to the particularity understanding of safety in STAMP , the connotation of safety has been substantially improved from the introduction of concepts such as hierarchical models , process models , and safety constraints .
#Text=2.3 .
#Text=System-Therotical Process Analysis ( STPA )
#Text=STPA is a new hazard analysis technique based on system safety theory .
#Text=According to the above-mentioned description , an accident is defined as the result of a complex process in which the system behavior goes against the safety constraints .
#Text=The main steps of STPA can be shown as follows :
#Text=Step 1 : Identify improper control actions of the system that may cause danger ,
#Text=Step 2 : Determine how potential hazard controls may occur in step 1 .
